turns.text: My names Mary Dell and I live in the Dallas Texas area where theres lot of pollution

turns.label: b

turns.text: Okay um just in particular here in the Twin Cities we have lot of big corporations and um --
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- Im sure theres lot of pollution We uh - before moving to Wisconsin lived across from where they were um gravel pits --
-- and also where they were making tar and so we would occasionally if the wind was blowing the right direction would get the smell of tar and --
-- it would uh - smell the continuous - you knew that you were also breathing that into your lungs so --
-- and it was like miles away but just the idea of having that come across the way it did in the wind --
-- kind of made you know that there was lot of pollution and that was just one small corporation that was doing the pollution of that but --
-- also um where we also lived too it was very close to highway so got lot of fumes from uh trucks --
-- and cars and you would literally see the pollution on your furniture I mean it was --
-- on your tables you would dust every day and it was dirty um type of dust I mean it wasnt the typical dust that you get way out in the country --
-- for - I live in small um town now quite ways from the Twin Cities about an hour away and I may dust once week and thats all it needs versus every day when I lived in the city --
-- Id never thought about that being cause I have to dust lot as well
Oh yeah it it comes right on through --
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- through the screens the only way that you could actually live in the in the city is to close your windows and have an air cleaner system right in your home --
-- that would take the air from the outside and clean the air before it would get into the house --
-- and so it was quite dirty city Um if you were well protected by trees which catch lot of the pollution --

turns.text: -- then youre fine but most of the time in the city you have lots of high rises you have lots of other things that are not catching the pollution and its just going --

Thats kind of the way Dallas is Were so flat and open and I live in suburb that doesnt have much vegetation trees --

-- an airport I work in building Im nineteen floors up --
-- and I look out toward International and theres just an awful brown haze all the time --

turns.text: Oh sure sure yeah Its - I mean our air quality um in the Twin Cities is lot better than what weve heard about California and --
turns.label: b

turns.text: -- my husband was uh talking to some of the guys at work now hes uh fifteen miles away from work but he was talking wouldnt it be nice to carpool and the guy says Well its too close it wouldnt pay --
Want to meet my own schedule --

turns.text: -- those are the arguments we hear
ex- exactly and so my husband says Well thats fine you know it would save quite bit on the wear and tear on cars --

turns.text: -- and you know the gas and no everybody has their preference to drive by themselves or if they do they they drive with one little buddy uh at least its with one person --

turns.label: sv(^q)

turns.text: Yes we are and I think of my daughter and Im sure you think of your children and you kind of say to yourself what kind of future will they have when they think back and say well my parents did have the choice to kind of make difference --
turns.label: aa

turns.text: -- and maybe people are trying but they have to change attitudes

turns.text: And it seems to me that its already so evident with our children having lot more respiratory infections --
